VOL. XXVIII, No. 15

THE JOHNS IIOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 23, 1923

REGIMENT 0. D. K. INITIATES FACULTY IMMEDIATE PURCHASE OF
FlOPKINS-FIFTH
TICKETS FOR MD. GAME
MEMBER AND UNDERGAMES TO BE STAGED
GRADUATES
URGED BY A. A. BOARD
FEBRUARY 21
Number of Entries Greater Than in Semi-Annual Public Initiation Held at Response of Students Found Unsatisfactory. Better Rooting Wanted
Weekly Assembly. Formal BanFormer Years
quet Last Night
Johns IIopkins students are

This year the Johns HopkinsFifth Regiment Game will be held
on the night of February 21. The
brilliant meets of former years will
be eclipsed by that to be run off the
night before Washington's Birthday, not only in the quality, but
likewise in the quantity of the participants. More colleges have indicated their intention to send teams
than ever before at such an early
date: Yale, Navy, Penn State, Pittsburgh, Maryland and the University
of Virginia being among the more
prominent of such early entries.
The Committee on Arrangements
has practically completed all of the
minor details, and the only cloud
on the horizon is the dispute with
Georgetown University over the
date. Georgetown claims that the
A. A. U. allotted the night of February 21 to them, and they plan to
hold their meet on that night. Hopkins, however, seems to be the favorite to get the date when the
national body at Detroit gives out
the plans next week.
In spite of the large number of
entries that is expected the program
will not be long or drawn out. The
plan which ended the carnival at
such a reasonable hour last year will
be followed, and only attractions of
general and popular interest will be
included. So there will be no dull
moments at any time during the
evening.
100 and Mile Run to Be Features

The greatest interest will be in
the two feature events; the invitation hundred yard dash, and the
invitation mile run. In the former
such men as Murchison, Fish, McCallister, Lovejoy, Lever and Louis
Clarke, Hopkins, are sure to run,
while numbers of other prominent
dash men are being sought, and will
probably be on hand. This event will
include the best of the country, and
will heip decide the hundred-yard
championship.
In the mile, Joie Ray, Willie Retola, Connelly and Verne Booth, the
intercollegiate two-mile and crossCountry champion, will compete.
This will be the greatest assembly
of distance men ever gathered on
a Baltimore track. Additional interest is manifested because of the
fact that Booth is one of the few
men to beat Ray to the winner's
tape, and because there is an intense
rivalry between the men. Hopkins
is strongly represented in both
events by Booth and Clarke.
Relays Will Hold Stage

Special relays between colleges
Will hold the stage a greater part of
the evening, and many close races
can be looked for. Scholastic teams
Will compete for the Cornell cup,
and Johns Hopkins will defend its
-Medley Relay Championship against
suitable picked opponents.
The meet is the only one in the
East to be run that evening, consequently .the greatest stars are sure
to be on hand. The committee is
Sparing no pains to secure the best
men and events.

FROSH TEAM TO PLAY MILTON ACADEMY
The Freshman football team is
entering the last lap before the allimportant Sophomore game. Only
one other game remains on the
schedule, the one with Milton Academy, to be played tomorrow at
12.30. The embryo pharmacists
probably will have the advantage
in age and weight, but the Freshmen should more than make it up
by teamwork and the benefit of
good coaching.
The squad has been reduced and
Captain Stone now has about twenty-five men working out each afternoon under Coach "Torn" Landy.
They were somewhat crippled when
the Student Council declared two
regulars ineligible, but this is somewhat offset by the fact that another
of the doubtful ones, Brian, has
gone under regulations and become
a full-fledged Freshie ; and that
"Otts" Niner has declared his intention of coming out shortly before
the game.
The tentative lineup for the
Freshmen against Milton Academy
is: L. E., Nichols; L. T., Stone; L.
G., Broening; C., Frank; R. G.
Stienwald ; R. T., Balke ; R. E..
Brown; O. B., Gough; R. H.,
Grinsfelder ; L. H., Cone; F. B.,
Brian.

Another cause of dissatisfaction
to the Board is the poor cheering.
All four classes are to blame for
this; the freshmen, because they
seem to lack the proper school
spirit—the spirit that cheers as
heartily at a bad fumble, as at a
brilliant play; the sophomores, because they either cannot or will
not make Freshmen cheer and do
not cheer themselves; the juniors
and seniors because they do not
seem interested enough in their
team to root for it.
Motions concerning appropriations for the rifle team and the tennis team were tabled until after the
football season.
A. A. Office Moved

Change in the location of the Athletic Office from the "Barn" to
Suite B-11 in the Alumni Memorial
Dormitory was made this week, in
order to get more working space.
Two rooms formerly occupied by
the office will be used by the NEWSLETTER and correspondents of the
Baltimore Sun. The editorial office Of the NEWS-LETTER will be
moved to the upper room, the business department to retain the room
now used by both dpeartments.
The Baltimore Sun will occupy
the lower office to facilitate the
handling of news from Johns Hopkins by a corps of reporters.
Moving will be completed this
week.

PRICE 5 CENTS

Schacht on Injured List

TRACK
Hopkins' cross country club will
journey to College Park Saturday,
November 23, to participate in the
South Atlantic Cross Country
Championship. The team will be
in good shape for the meet and expects to make record time over
the University of Maryland
course. According to Captain
Booth, the team is scheduled to
win.
The Cross Country Club lost a
good chance to win the Middle
Atlantic Cross Country Championship held last Saturday in
New York city, because of lack of
finances and development of sore
ankles by several of the members.
With a rest afforded by the rainy
days last week the team is expected to be in fine shape for the meet
this Saturday.

Eddie Schacht, left end on the
Hopkins team, is still out of the
game with an injured ankle, which
he received in the St. John's contest two weeks a.p-o. Schacht will
be missed in the line-up tomorrow
but he has an able successor in
Berndt, who has had several opportunities t , display his ability
this season. Day, who also sustained a bad ankle in the St.
Johh's game, is almost cured and
it is most likely that he will be
seen at cent-n- tomorrow aftern
Fortur at ly the injured
list has called no other Hopkins
players from action.
Sigma Chi Beta Dance tomorrow, C. E. Hall, at 8.30
P.M.
There will not be a dance
after tomorrow's game.

Major Gregory Hoisington, for

commandant
of the military unit

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 23, 1923

GET ACQUAINTED WITH HOPKINS
"Do we play up local features like we should ?" Thus begins a
bulletin issued by the Merchants and Manufacturers' Association, an
organization composed of leading business men of the city. This
organ goes on to say:
"It is marvelous how some people can wax enthusiastic and energetic about something connected with another city and be as dead as
a piece of granite about the same thing in their own city. Baltimore
is a university city. It has here a university with an international
reputation. If the Johns Hopkins University were in some other
city, the very atmosphere would be saturated with the college spirit.
Indeed, the "college spirit" is good for any community. There is
something breezy about it which favorably affects everybody. In
New Haven, the big business men play hand-in-glove with Yale. In
Boston, the word "Harvard" is synonymous with the business circle.
The Princeton feeling pervades all of New Jersey. Not that the business men all went to said universities. But they have caught the
spirit.. They are in sympathy with it. They encourage it. Why
not the same here? Our business men should be as deeply interested in Johns Hopkins' College Life as Bostonians are in Harvard. Our
business circle should warm up energetically and earnestly in Johns
Hopkins athletics. Indeed, if we could get the swing of this general
"college spirit," our hearts would beat faster and our life would assume one more ray of brighter hue. Hopkins has more athletic
dates ahead. Why not put Baltimore behind the boys in a way that
business men know how to do. Not just a few business men, but
everybody !"
We are indeed grateful that Baltimore has begun to take cognizance of the fact that "it has here a university of international reputation." Hopkins and Hopkins' activities constitute the best national advertisement that Baltimore possesses.
And while over
twenty-five thousand people view a mediocre football game at the
Baltimore Stadium, barely five thousand attend a classic, the Hopkins-St. John's game at Homewood Field.
We give the business men and the general public plenty of opportunity to "get acquainted with Hopkins." Baltimore's support would
prove of great advantage to Hopkins. And we feel that Hopkins'
activities can prove advantageous to Baltimore.

THE 0. D. K. ELECTIONS
Three members of the Senior Class have been awarded the key
of the Omicron Delta Kappa Honorary Fraternity and have thus, according to undergraduate opinion, become recipients of the greatest
honor which a Hopkins man can obtain during his college career. The
News-Letter wishes to extend congratulations to the new initiates.
The number of men taken into 0. D. K. in this election proved
unusually small. Three per cent, of the undergraduate body are eligible for admission during a collegiate year. The fact that only three
men, out of an approximate enrollment of seven hundred were elected
shows that the standards of selection are high. We feel, however,
that this will make undergraduates strive the hearder to achieve the
honor.

The Greetings of a Fine Store
To the Students of a Fine University

*

HOCHSCHILD,KOHN 8,c,Co.

After the games of last Saturday,
Cornell and Yale stood out as the
greatest teams of the East. Syracuse, a contender until Saturday,
lost to Colgate in one of the greatest upsets of the season. The outcome of the Yale-Harvard game
and Cornell-Penn. game on Thanksgiving Day will consequently settle
the mythical 'championship of the
East. Cornell will have to go some
to gain the decision over Yale, because of Penn. State's victory over
Penn. last week.
* * *
In the Big Ten Conference, Illinois and Michigan have won every
conference contest, and Minnesota
has won every game except that
against Wisconsin, which was a tie.
Should Minnesota beat Michigan on
Saturday, Illinois would probably
be the champion, as she should have
little trouble in defeating Ohio
State.
Princeton finished one of the
most unsuccessful seasons in Tiger
football history when Yale took
them into camp by the overwhelming score of 27-0. This season's
string of defeats at the hands of
Notre Dame, Harvard and Yale
eclipses the success of last season's
undefeated team.
*

*

Hopkins has the unusual record
of holding Cornell scoreless during
a period of a game. This is something no other team has been able
to do this season.
*
California is still undefeated and
Stanford is the only team that
stands in their road to another undefeated season. Stanford beat Nevada 20-0 early in the season, and
Nevada held California to a scoreless tie. On the other hand, the
University of Southern California
has defeated Stanford and lost to
California.
•
*
Hopkins has for the last two
years looked upon the Army-Navy
game in the light of Hopkins glory
through the starring of Wood,
Army, and Barchet, Navy, both former Hopkins men. In 1921, when
Army was defeated 7-0, these two
Players starred for their respective
teams beyond a shadow of a doubt,
and last year they were again in
the limelight. What they will do
tomorrow when the service teams
meet again remains to be seen.
*

*

Dinsmore, Tiger quarterback,
Was not responsible for the fumble which resulted in Harvard's
field goal, as was stated in last
Sunday's papers. The ball never
touched Dinsmore, but brushed
Rgainst Beattie, a halfback.

Real Service Must Be Engineered
Many of the men whose names are writ large
in engineering history are design engineers; men
like Westinghouse, Lamme, Stanley, Hodgkinson, Tesla, Shallenberger. Their inventions
have the quality of usefulness, of reliability, of
productability; which is an involved way, perhaps, of saying that they have the primary
requisite of all really great inventions:
Serviceability.
Engineering history abounds in instances of
near-genius that produced no product, and of
great developments that never reached completion; and most of these instances are explained
by the lack, somewhere in the system, of that
ability to give real Service.
Service, in a machine or a system, or wherever
you find it, is not there by accident but because
it was incorporated by men who understood
what was required and knew how to provide it.
Much more is required of the designer than
facility in calculation and mastery of theory.
He must have first hand and thorough familiarity
with manufacturing operations and with commercial and operating conditions. It takes more
than mere ingenuity and inventiveness to design
apparatus that will be really serviceable and
will "stay put."

The design engineer, in the Westinghouse
plan, is responsible for the performance of the
finished product. He cannot possibly have the
proper understanding of operation unless he operates and tests, unless he spends time and thought
in investigation and study, not in the laboratory
or drawing room, but right on the operating
job. Here, most of his ideas will develop; and
here he will see and prepare for all the different
things which the product will later have to
encounter. Then when he comes to put his
creations on paper, his calculations will be
necessary and helpful to check the conclusions
which he has reached, and this right use of them
requires training and a high degree of understanding. This proper balance of the physical
and mathematical conception of things is what
constitutes engineering judgement.
It should be thoroughly understood that the
primary function of the design engineer is the
conception and the production of new or improved apparatus, and familiarity with the
practical is essential to the proper discharge of
this duty.
It is this view of designing that makes this
branch of Westinghouse engineering so important, so effective, and so productive of real
developments.

Westinghouse
ACHIEVEMENT

THE JOHNS IIOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 23, 1923

REGIMENT 0. D. K. INITIATES FACULTY IMMEDIATE PURCHASE OF
FlOPKINS-FIFTH
TICKETS FOR MD. GAME
MEMBER AND UNDERGAMES TO BE STAGED
GRADUATES
URGED BY A. A. BOARD
FEBRUARY 21
Number of Entries Greater Than in Semi-Annual Public Initiation Held at Response of Students Found Unsatisfactory. Better Rooting Wanted
Weekly Assembly. Formal BanFormer Years
quet Last Night
Johns IIopkins students are

This year the Johns HopkinsFifth Regiment Game will be held
on the night of February 21. The
brilliant meets of former years will
be eclipsed by that to be run off the
night before Washington's Birthday, not only in the quality, but
likewise in the quantity of the participants. More colleges have indicated their intention to send teams
than ever before at such an early
date: Yale, Navy, Penn State, Pittsburgh, Maryland and the University
of Virginia being among the more
prominent of such early entries.
The Committee on Arrangements
has practically completed all of the
minor details, and the only cloud
on the horizon is the dispute with
Georgetown University over the
date. Georgetown claims that the
A. A. U. allotted the night of February 21 to them, and they plan to
hold their meet on that night. Hopkins, however, seems to be the favorite to get the date when the
national body at Detroit gives out
the plans next week.
In spite of the large number of
entries that is expected the program
will not be long or drawn out. The
plan which ended the carnival at
such a reasonable hour last year will
be followed, and only attractions of
general and popular interest will be
included. So there will be no dull
moments at any time during the
evening.
100 and Mile Run to Be Features

The greatest interest will be in
the two feature events; the invitation hundred yard dash, and the
invitation mile run. In the former
such men as Murchison, Fish, McCallister, Lovejoy, Lever and Louis
Clarke, Hopkins, are sure to run,
while numbers of other prominent
dash men are being sought, and will
probably be on hand. This event will
include the best of the country, and
will heip decide the hundred-yard
championship.
In the mile, Joie Ray, Willie Retola, Connelly and Verne Booth, the
intercollegiate two-mile and crossCountry champion, will compete.
This will be the greatest assembly
of distance men ever gathered on
a Baltimore track. Additional interest is manifested because of the
fact that Booth is one of the few
men to beat Ray to the winner's
tape, and because there is an intense
rivalry between the men. Hopkins
is strongly represented in both
events by Booth and Clarke.
Relays Will Hold Stage

Special relays between colleges
Will hold the stage a greater part of
the evening, and many close races
can be looked for. Scholastic teams
Will compete for the Cornell cup,
and Johns Hopkins will defend its
-Medley Relay Championship against
suitable picked opponents.
The meet is the only one in the
East to be run that evening, consequently .the greatest stars are sure
to be on hand. The committee is
Sparing no pains to secure the best
men and events.

FROSH TEAM TO PLAY MILTON ACADEMY
The Freshman football team is
entering the last lap before the allimportant Sophomore game. Only
one other game remains on the
schedule, the one with Milton Academy, to be played tomorrow at
12.30. The embryo pharmacists
probably will have the advantage
in age and weight, but the Freshmen should more than make it up
by teamwork and the benefit of
good coaching.
The squad has been reduced and
Captain Stone now has about twenty-five men working out each afternoon under Coach "Torn" Landy.
They were somewhat crippled when
the Student Council declared two
regulars ineligible, but this is somewhat offset by the fact that another
of the doubtful ones, Brian, has
gone under regulations and become
a full-fledged Freshie ; and that
"Otts" Niner has declared his intention of coming out shortly before
the game.
The tentative lineup for the
Freshmen against Milton Academy
is: L. E., Nichols; L. T., Stone; L.
G., Broening; C., Frank; R. G.
Stienwald ; R. T., Balke ; R. E..
Brown; O. B., Gough; R. H.,
Grinsfelder ; L. H., Cone; F. B.,
Brian.

Another cause of dissatisfaction
to the Board is the poor cheering.
All four classes are to blame for
this; the freshmen, because they
seem to lack the proper school
spirit—the spirit that cheers as
heartily at a bad fumble, as at a
brilliant play; the sophomores, because they either cannot or will
not make Freshmen cheer and do
not cheer themselves; the juniors
and seniors because they do not
seem interested enough in their
team to root for it.
Motions concerning appropriations for the rifle team and the tennis team were tabled until after the
football season.
A. A. Office Moved

Change in the location of the Athletic Office from the "Barn" to
Suite B-11 in the Alumni Memorial
Dormitory was made this week, in
order to get more working space.
Two rooms formerly occupied by
the office will be used by the NEWSLETTER and correspondents of the
Baltimore Sun. The editorial office Of the NEWS-LETTER will be
moved to the upper room, the business department to retain the room
now used by both dpeartments.
The Baltimore Sun will occupy
the lower office to facilitate the
handling of news from Johns Hopkins by a corps of reporters.
Moving will be completed this
week.

PRICE 5 CENTS

Schacht on Injured List

TRACK
Hopkins' cross country club will
journey to College Park Saturday,
November 23, to participate in the
South Atlantic Cross Country
Championship. The team will be
in good shape for the meet and expects to make record time over
the University of Maryland
course. According to Captain
Booth, the team is scheduled to
win.
The Cross Country Club lost a
good chance to win the Middle
Atlantic Cross Country Championship held last Saturday in
New York city, because of lack of
finances and development of sore
ankles by several of the members.
With a rest afforded by the rainy
days last week the team is expected to be in fine shape for the meet
this Saturday.

Eddie Schacht, left end on the
Hopkins team, is still out of the
game with an injured ankle, which
he received in the St. John's contest two weeks a.p-o. Schacht will
be missed in the line-up tomorrow
but he has an able successor in
Berndt, who has had several opportunities t , display his ability
this season. Day, who also sustained a bad ankle in the St.
Johh's game, is almost cured and
it is most likely that he will be
seen at cent-n- tomorrow aftern
Fortur at ly the injured
list has called no other Hopkins
players from action.
Sigma Chi Beta Dance tomorrow, C. E. Hall, at 8.30
P.M.
There will not be a dance
after tomorrow's game.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 23, 1923

GET ACQUAINTED WITH HOPKINS
"Do we play up local features like we should ?" Thus begins a
bulletin issued by the Merchants and Manufacturers' Association, an
organization composed of leading business men of the city. This
organ goes on to say:
"It is marvelous how some people can wax enthusiastic and energetic about something connected with another city and be as dead as
a piece of granite about the same thing in their own city. Baltimore
is a university city. It has here a university with an international
reputation. If the Johns Hopkins University were in some other
city, the very atmosphere would be saturated with the college spirit.
Indeed, the "college spirit" is good for any community. There is
something breezy about it which favorably affects everybody. In
New Haven, the big business men play hand-in-glove with Yale. In
Boston, the word "Harvard" is synonymous with the business circle.
The Princeton feeling pervades all of New Jersey. Not that the business men all went to said universities. But they have caught the
spirit.. They are in sympathy with it. They encourage it. Why
not the same here? Our business men should be as deeply interested in Johns Hopkins' College Life as Bostonians are in Harvard. Our
business circle should warm up energetically and earnestly in Johns
Hopkins athletics. Indeed, if we could get the swing of this general
"college spirit," our hearts would beat faster and our life would assume one more ray of brighter hue. Hopkins has more athletic
dates ahead. Why not put Baltimore behind the boys in a way that
business men know how to do. Not just a few business men, but
everybody !"
We are indeed grateful that Baltimore has begun to take cognizance of the fact that "it has here a university of international reputation." Hopkins and Hopkins' activities constitute the best national advertisement that Baltimore possesses.
And while over
twenty-five thousand people view a mediocre football game at the
Baltimore Stadium, barely five thousand attend a classic, the Hopkins-St. John's game at Homewood Field.
We give the business men and the general public plenty of opportunity to "get acquainted with Hopkins." Baltimore's support would
prove of great advantage to Hopkins. And we feel that Hopkins'
activities can prove advantageous to Baltimore.

THE 0. D. K. ELECTIONS
Three members of the Senior Class have been awarded the key
of the Omicron Delta Kappa Honorary Fraternity and have thus, according to undergraduate opinion, become recipients of the greatest
honor which a Hopkins man can obtain during his college career. The
News-Letter wishes to extend congratulations to the new initiates.
The number of men taken into 0. D. K. in this election proved
unusually small. Three per cent, of the undergraduate body are eligible for admission during a collegiate year. The fact that only three
men, out of an approximate enrollment of seven hundred were elected
shows that the standards of selection are high. We feel, however,
that this will make undergraduates strive the hearder to achieve the
honor.

HOCHSCHILD,KOHN 8,c,Co.

After the games of last Saturday,
Cornell and Yale stood out as the
greatest teams of the East. Syracuse, a contender until Saturday,
lost to Colgate in one of the greatest upsets of the season. The outcome of the Yale-Harvard game
and Cornell-Penn. game on Thanksgiving Day will consequently settle
the mythical 'championship of the
East. Cornell will have to go some
to gain the decision over Yale, because of Penn. State's victory over
Penn. last week.
* * *
In the Big Ten Conference, Illinois and Michigan have won every
conference contest, and Minnesota
has won every game except that
against Wisconsin, which was a tie.
Should Minnesota beat Michigan on
Saturday, Illinois would probably
be the champion, as she should have
little trouble in defeating Ohio
State.
Princeton finished one of the
most unsuccessful seasons in Tiger
football history when Yale took
them into camp by the overwhelming score of 27-0. This season's
string of defeats at the hands of
Notre Dame, Harvard and Yale
eclipses the success of last season's
undefeated team.
*

*

Hopkins has the unusual record
of holding Cornell scoreless during
a period of a game. This is something no other team has been able
to do this season.
*
California is still undefeated and
Stanford is the only team that
stands in their road to another undefeated season. Stanford beat Nevada 20-0 early in the season, and
Nevada held California to a scoreless tie. On the other hand, the
University of Southern California
has defeated Stanford and lost to
California.
•
*
Hopkins has for the last two
years looked upon the Army-Navy
game in the light of Hopkins glory
through the starring of Wood,
Army, and Barchet, Navy, both former Hopkins men. In 1921, when
Army was defeated 7-0, these two
Players starred for their respective
teams beyond a shadow of a doubt,
and last year they were again in
the limelight. What they will do
tomorrow when the service teams
meet again remains to be seen.
*

*

Dinsmore, Tiger quarterback,
Was not responsible for the fumble which resulted in Harvard's
field goal, as was stated in last
Sunday's papers. The ball never
touched Dinsmore, but brushed
Rgainst Beattie, a halfback.

Real Service Must Be Engineered
Many of the men whose names are writ large
in engineering history are design engineers; men
like Westinghouse, Lamme, Stanley, Hodgkinson, Tesla, Shallenberger. Their inventions
have the quality of usefulness, of reliability, of
productability; which is an involved way, perhaps, of saying that they have the primary
requisite of all really great inventions:
Serviceability.
Engineering history abounds in instances of
near-genius that produced no product, and of
great developments that never reached completion; and most of these instances are explained
by the lack, somewhere in the system, of that
ability to give real Service.
Service, in a machine or a system, or wherever
you find it, is not there by accident but because
it was incorporated by men who understood
what was required and knew how to provide it.
Much more is required of the designer than
facility in calculation and mastery of theory.
He must have first hand and thorough familiarity
with manufacturing operations and with commercial and operating conditions. It takes more
than mere ingenuity and inventiveness to design
apparatus that will be really serviceable and
will "stay put."

The design engineer, in the Westinghouse
plan, is responsible for the performance of the
finished product. He cannot possibly have the
proper understanding of operation unless he operates and tests, unless he spends time and thought
in investigation and study, not in the laboratory
or drawing room, but right on the operating
job. Here, most of his ideas will develop; and
here he will see and prepare for all the different
things which the product will later have to
encounter. Then when he comes to put his
creations on paper, his calculations will be
necessary and helpful to check the conclusions
which he has reached, and this right use of them
requires training and a high degree of understanding. This proper balance of the physical
and mathematical conception of things is what
constitutes engineering judgement.
It should be thoroughly understood that the
primary function of the design engineer is the
conception and the production of new or improved apparatus, and familiarity with the
practical is essential to the proper discharge of
this duty.
It is this view of designing that makes this
branch of Westinghouse engineering so important, so effective, and so productive of real
developments.

Westinghouse
